title: 4 Things You DON'T Need for College!

comments.text:
$60 work of ink (XL Version from Costco) lasts me 3 full semesters with 
some printing in between. You definitely need a printer in college now a 
days. So many times I wouldve been screwed if I didn't have one. Libraries, 
Computer Labs and businesses close at certain times and open and certain 
times, your home printer wont close on you. A MUST!﻿
comments.author: Christopher Barron

comments.text:
+Christopher Barron I'm currently going to a University where printing is 
free, you just have to supply the paper. I found home printers a hassle 
that always seemed to break and had to have ink replaced. And the printer 
building was open from 8am-8pm which is pretty convenient.
comments.author: Kyle Booker

comments.text: I've had my very own bank account and debit card since I was 14﻿
comments.author: BeMoGamer

comments.text: You save more money using you're own computer and printer end of story.﻿
comments.author: Epica124

comments.text:
i feel like if you went out of the country to a college such as one in 
denmark you will still get a very good education please you wont have to be 
in debt 400000﻿
comments.author: Victor Warner

comments.text:
You know it would still be hard because of citizenship and living 
conditionds but some of the best educated ppl come from foreign countries i 
was thinking about going to sweden for medical
comments.author: Victor Warner

comments.text:
Yeah, same with most parts in Germany and I believe all of Switzerland, 
too. I'm actually considering going to Germany or the others as an American 
student because it can get wayyy pricey over here in America.
comments.author: Leslie Dapple

comments.text: Shut up hoe﻿
comments.author: niguhpleaze

comments.text: i like these college videos thx!﻿
comments.author: jordaii sandoval

comments.text:
I had to get a printer because I'm required to print some many different 
things for my classes where all of my printing credits would be used up 
within half the semester. Printer was was $70 and i have to get new ink 
every 6 months (which is about $15). Also you can establish credit by 
paying bills and rent on time. If you're going to get a credit card, get it 
at some place like kohl's so you have somewhat of a limit and then pay it 
in full the next month. Don't do those visa or master card credit cards. 
Bad idea.﻿
comments.author: EclipseAMV

comments.text:
I have no student loan or dept and I lived on a cheap place. Yay free 
education!﻿
comments.author: Idellle

comments.text:
And doubly thanks for wasting my time. Bitch just shut your trap!! For the

comments.text: Thanks for the bad advice﻿

comments.text:
video 4, and bubbly airhead has me too pissed to keep watching this

comments.text:
Get a debit card, I don't think I'll ever get a credit card cause you don't 
need it, you want it.﻿
comments.author: adrian gil

comments.text:
yeah but I don't consider buying a house a neccesary thing and if I were to 
buy a new car I will need a good credit. I can always pay monthly rent and 
buy a used car. I just trying to say you really don't need a credit card to 
live under capitalism.
comments.author: adrian gil

comments.text:
You're yet young...I chucked my credit cards because I felt I didn't need 
them...but you will need an established credit history to purchase a car or 
a house...

comments.text:
I mainly use my debit card, but I also have a credit card for bigger 
purchases, but always make sure you can pay off the minimum balance every 
month. If you're smart about it you won't have any problems.

comments.text: Why are these subtitles so inaccurate?﻿

is there any real reason for textbooks wen almost every college student has

all of the info in that book is 100% on the internet for free. ﻿

comments.text: Use your library.  Some offer loans for a week at a time.  ﻿

comments.text: damn shes cute﻿

comments.text: Do not worship at the altar of the FICO score! -Dave Ramsey﻿
comments.author: Jared Alfred

comments.text: Also, don't forget to about The American Opportunity Tax Credit. ﻿
comments.author: Jose Perez

comments.text:
I got a credit card as soon as i was 18, I had a limit of 800 dollars. It 
has increased now that I'm 19 and I've never been late on payments and only 
use it when I know I can pay it off. ﻿
comments.author: Jose Perez

comments.text: Smart.
comments.author: Peter Parker

comments.text:
We are actually required to have a laptop to attend many classes in 
Denmark. But then again - we get paid to go to college/university. :P

 Also, you can get a laser printer (the cheapest one) if you can't afford 
ink. I got mine for $170 and it prints at least 1200 pages (usually closer 
to 1600) on each cartridge, that only costs a few bucks extra compared to 
ink that may print 250 pages before running out.﻿
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
+Ryan Docherty Uuuh, you don't have to look that hard on google to see that 
we get paid to go to school in all the Nordic countries, except Iceland. 
There is also no tuition in any Nordic country.

Besides, I'm not rich, nor am I snobby. My parents are middle class.
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
I highly doubt that and if you do you go to a rich prep school college for 
stuck up snobby rich fucks like you
comments.author: Ryan Docherty

comments.text:
I like most of the european countries because of this innovation and a 
smart population theme.  But I still got a real apprenticeship with DR 
Oetker (no interest in further school at the moment). I am a really luck 
guy to get such a secure and well paid job with a great company. I will 
learn a lot from them even though I am not studying. ;D
comments.author: StalkingHawk

comments.text:
+tfmuggleblood Oh, but that is the general idea of why we get paid. The 
idea of "equal opportunity" no matter of background.

Thanks. :)
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
+Lemonz1989 That's great! I don't think your explanation sufficed though. I 
might have to do more in-depth research on it. Well, good luck on your 
studies. :)
comments.author: tfmuggleblood

comments.text:
+tfmuggleblood It's because Denmark has few natural resources and the 
economy in a large degree runs on innovation, so they (the people and 
government) want a well educated workforce, and believe that social or 
economic standing shouldn't be a hindrance to getting a good education. :)

We are required to have laptops, because a lot of our school work is 
electronic. Much of our reading material is in the form of e-books. We 
deliver written assignments through an online system that most schools are 
connected to. No paper assignments. :P
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
+Lemonz1989 Mostyl why you guys gets paid, but a laptop explanation would 
be cool too. It's really interesting.
comments.author: tfmuggleblood

comments.text:
+tfmuggleblood Why what? :) Why we get paid, or why we are required to use 
laptops?
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text: +Lemonz1989 Why tho?
comments.author: tfmuggleblood

comments.text: IM PACKIN
comments.author: Steven “SkylessSkyrim” McElroy

comments.text: +Jad Jurdy that's the cost of a decent education here
comments.author: Hayden Voegtle

comments.text: lol that's too much 50,000/year is way over the line !
comments.author: Jad Jurdy

comments.text: well I pay $50,000/year for college - and I don't get paid
comments.author: Hayden Voegtle

comments.text:
+Mario Kirchsteiger The money we get in Denmark is dependent on our 
parents' income up to the age of 20, then we get the full amount, unless we 
are still living at home with our parents. :)
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
In Germany and Austria we have a similar system, you usually also get paid 
for college. The amount of money is dependent on your parents income. In my 
opinion this is totally fair, because rich people dont get paid that much 
(but they can afford it anyway) and people with a lower income get more
comments.author: Mario Kirchsteiger

comments.text:
in NZ we have loans and a free allowance for students. we do have to pay 
for 25% of our fee's so mine are on my student loan so about $7000 a year. 
i get like $200 a week free allowance (aka don't need to pay back) for 10 
years or till i finish uni. our loans are completely interest free
comments.author: Pharom

comments.text:
+Jad Jurdy No, I'm not kidding. :) We have no tuition and we get paid. 
Almost all the Nordic countries have a similar system. :)
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text: come one man ur kidding right ?
comments.author: Jad Jurdy

comments.text:
+Lemonz1989 sounds great honestly, here in the netherlands we do have debts 
after college and i hate it :/
comments.author: Saif Rashed

comments.text:
+Saif Rashed We can take government backed loans that have 4% interest 
while studying and 1% interest after you're done. If we want to take them 
depends on how fancy we want to live. I live in government owned school 
housing, so it's pretty cheap - around $550 a month, electricity around $30 
a month and heating around $20. I have no other expenses other than food, 
which I can usually squeeze down to about $110 a month if I buy raw 
materials and make the food myself. So no real debts for me. :)
I do, however, have a loan of $1700 for the deposit, but I can pay that 
back when I move out of my apartment and get my deposit back. :)
comments.author: Lemonz1989

comments.text:
If you absolutely have to buy a new, several hundred dollar textbook, don't 
even bother reselling it at the end of the semester.  They will literally 
give you $10 for a $300 book.  Just keep the thing.  With most math and 
science courses you won't get all the way through the book so it will still 
have some information you haven't seen.  At the very least, it's worth more 
as a quick reference than the $5 they'll give you for it.﻿
comments.author: Chris J.

comments.text: How am I supposed to do my cad projects without a computer﻿
comments.author: mike777881

comments.text: I get my textbooks free from my teacher﻿
comments.author: Sofie Rouse

comments.text:
+BreezyHorn Wow. I can't believe we got free textbooks back then. 
Especially considering I live in a poor Black neighborhood. Unbelievable.

comments.text:
This girl is smart. I explain to so many people my age that credit cards 
can be a good thing if you make them work for you! Right now I have 3 
credit cards, a 789 credit score, and $0 of college debt! Build your credit 
history! It will save you money in the long run! ﻿

comments.text:
Selling students the things they "need" for college is a huge business. 
Decide for yourself what's  important to you - think critically about your

comments.text: Love Chegg.com. And they send me Redbull and coffee and energy shots. ﻿

comments.text:
A great way to save money on text book is to get the old editions. I once 
bought a 12 dollar old text book for a class and the material was the exact 
same as the new book.﻿

comments.text: Yeah I have chicken legs. Can't wear shorts. 110lbs of pure awesomeness :)﻿

comments.author: Madie Doyle

comments.text:
the top thing you don't need for college is majoring in a liberal arts 
degree that wouldn't land you a job.﻿
comments.author: AmandaNerdBot

comments.text:
For my biology/anatomy physiology class, we had online assignments worth 10 
percent, and the access code came with a digital and hardback textbook 
which was $300. We had an option of buying the digital textbook and access 
code online for $130, but it would expire within a year.So buying the 
hardback textbook was worth it since I would be using it for future 
reference.﻿
comments.author: roxo166

comments.text:
For my Math Class, they make the class have online assignments. So that the 
reason why I bought my math textbook new. Since I am in a support program, 
I use the money give to me. Sometime I have to buy it new because that is 
the only option available. I perfer to buy in the student bookstore so that 
I can have the books right way.
comments.author: Doan Nguyen

comments.text:
Paid printing?! Whaaat. So jealous. We had to pay 8-10 cents per page 
(which is not that pricey but it adds up over 6 years of post secondary)﻿
comments.author: Spiffleh

comments.text: You can get pdf's pretty easy nowadays﻿
comments.author: Mr3141592653ful

comments.text:
I could never sell back my engineering books.  They are too useful.  Ya 
sure sell your psychology book back or sociology book. Those are useless.  
But don't sell back your technical books.  I use mine years after 
graduating.

And no printer?! Screw that!  I'm not going to the library to print shiit 
out.  They are crazy.﻿
comments.author: impedancenetwork

comments.text: are you mad? let me guide you the best platform its panxcash the best﻿
comments.author: Abul Kalam

comments.text:
I bought books used from amazon, and sold back used through amazon (not 
directly to amazon for the gift card) and lost about $15-30 per book. Not 
bad considering books cost $100+ minimum.﻿
comments.author: buytamra3

comments.text:
I decided to work for about 3 years to save up money to prepare me for 
university life. I have a comfortable place to live, motorcycle, car and a 
large enough pool of money to support myself. Just don't live outside your 
means and set goals in terms of saving money.﻿

comments.text: U don't need a MacBook﻿

comments.text:
its a waste of money if you don't get a credit card.  as long as you pay it 
of 100% each month, you make money off the credit card companies.  if you 
can't be responsible, then of course don't get one.
comments.author: m1k3y~ミクト

comments.text: It's good to build a credit history to help with getting loans and things :)
comments.author: luckygreenstar22

comments.text:
When I was still new in canada, I walked door to door for a month begging 
for people to let me rent an apartment because I kept getting rejected for 
having no credit history. It's easier when you have parents or know people 
that can co-sign for you, but sadly, to be independent in north america 
means you have to get a credit card.
comments.author: JFrame

comments.text:
shit if you dont see what theyre used for then they must be pointless ill

I don't understand how you can sleep at night when you have a loan ! If you

comments.author: asulintunecat1

comments.text:
You guys (and girls) should do a video explaining how to pay down and pay 
off student loans because student loan debt, in about the past decade, has 
surpassed credit card debt as the biggest source of debt for most 
Americans. ﻿
comments.author: minstrel1184

comments.text:
The thing is, once you're out of college, if you took out loans, making 
your monthly loan payments 1) on time and then also, if you can afford to 
do so, 2) paying even just a little more than the minimum payment, is 
another way build your credit history and boost your credit score.  You 
don't NEED a credit card to do so.  That said, if you want to have one 
exclusively for things like the books that you need at the start of the 
semester and then you pay it off by the end of the semester, fine.  I think 
the trap that a lot of people fall into is, "Oh, this is just $8" and then 
the next day "Oh, this is just $15" and so on and so forth until, at the 
end of the month, they build up $150 in debt or so and they keep doing it 
and not ever getting it all paid off and then the problem snowballs.﻿
comments.author: minstrel1184

comments.text:
Here in the Netherlands you have to have an income of more than 1,200 euro 
    (1,635.36 dollar) to even get a credit card. And even than you can only 
'spend' 2000 euro or something.(2,725.6 dollar)﻿
comments.author: Ana Chantal

comments.text:
Yeah, in America, on average, comunity colleges cost about $6,000, state 
schools cost between $12,000-20,000 and private schools cost between 
$30,000-60,000
comments.author: allyouneedislove1030

comments.text:
+allyouneedislove1030 At the moment 1907 euro per year, without books and 
stuff. It does keep going up 100 euro every year. But it is much better 
than 10,000 dollar a year in USA. For non EU people is it 7000+, so it 
would also be almost 10,000 dollar. Only reason we pay 1907 is because of 
the government.
comments.author: Ana Chantal

comments.text:
University also only costs like 3,000 euro for you guys too, which is 
just.... UGHH SO JEALOUS!

comments.text: She's also a dumb bitch
comments.author: Donald Cedar

comments.text:
Get a credit card with a low limit. (We use ours for gas.) Pay it off every 
month. Not having credit history can screw you down the road. I've had my 
card for a year or two and "not enough history" is still bringing my credit 
score down.﻿
comments.author: LegoGirl1990

comments.text: +marilynn santos It will screw your life up bad if you are an idiot.
comments.author: Donald Cedar

comments.text:
+marilynn santos
Sorry, I got a little snarky. When we got our card, we were making roughly 
$43,000 and the card only has a $300 limit. It would be hard to get into 
trouble with such a low limit, and having the card, using it for gas and 
paying it off every month, has helped our credit considerably.
One thing to remember is to keep the balance at less than half of the limit.
comments.author: LegoGirl1990

comments.text: Just saying happen once to a friend, I know what it means- sorry

comments.author: deathtothegoths

comments.text:
deathtothegoths - I had the exact same problem as your friend....but I 
didn't ask for handouts. Honestly, I worked my butt off to get on SSI/SSDI 
and filled out the FAFSA. Now I almost have my 4 year degree and all on 
grants because I worked for it. Now I want to get my Masters', but that 
can't happen yet because of finances again. But I'm not setting up a 
website and asking for donations because I'm "too excited to wait", I'm 
just dealing with it and waiting until  I have a way of paying for it. 
Honestly, she'll probably only get donations from friends and family 
because they give a crap. The rest of the world? They don't. Even I think 
she is going about it all wrong and I was in the exact same situation as 
her (I also didn't start college until age 22). I am now 29 and just now 
about to graduate this May. Sometimes you just have to WAIT.
comments.author: Heather Cohen

comments.text:
not to defend you but many young adults are in this situate also so this 
website thing wont help at all. i recommend singing up for fafas or tax 
decrease paper.
comments.author: strawberryz girl123

comments.text:
At my university we have to pay for printing. I think a printer is 
completely worth the money, IF your university doesn't charge you for 
printing. You don't need an expensive one but especially moving off campus 
. I got mine as a graduation gift, so that might be a great thing to ask 
for, because those 2 page essays you seem to always be writing add up.﻿

comments.text:
+Lance Avion It might not be stepping the cpu high enough.. or a half-assed 
chipset driver. or even the sata controller not welcoming the switch to 
ext3 from ntfs. too many variables can make a computer "slow" browsing the 
web to blame it on the processor.
comments.author: bmw2go11

comments.text:
How much ram was on it and what was the hard drive speed. Processors have 
very little to do with loading times
comments.author: malrofo

comments.text:
I disagree. Unless you're using Chrome OS on an SSD an underpowered 
processor just wastes too much time loading things. For instance today I 
installed Ubuntu on an Intel Celeron based laptop. Compared to my i7 laptop 
with Windows 8 it loads web pages extremely slowly.

what I'm saying is if you do not have the money to pay for it in the 
present of future you cannot........ cannot be rational. it is more of a

comments.text:
Well I always planned on buying things figuring out if I could spend the 
money and then spending it. I wasn't going to the store to buy random 
things and I always paid my bills first. So, yes I and my therapist though 
I was rational when I was 'addicted' to shopping.

so you are saying you considered yourself a rational person at all times 
while having an addiction haha. thanks for proving my point

comments.text:
I lied not every thing is free, if average income you have to buy school 
books by your self after 9th grade , but even new ones heavily subsidizes 
by government but if from less fortunate family welfare pays those books 
And this concept of kicking out from primary school is totally strange 
here, they just wrote new law which makes duty to study to least until at 
age of 17
comments.author: John Stoner For Life 77

comments.text:
That last that you should have 2yr experience before starting is in some 
extent handled here so that specially those which teach working physically 
often is included some periods in real work environment, but I recognize 
same problem here in more academic jobs 
12 grade including high school?? I understood that school starts at age of 
6 in US? 
Our whole education in some extent starts with free kindergarten at the age 
of 2 and at age of 6 there is 1ye of volunteer pre-school where play is 
more important 
And at the age of 7 start primary school which is divided into two separate 
part to 1-6graders to 7-9 graders after that you choose either kind of you 
would call high school for those aiming to university lasting ....... 
lasting 2-4yrs depending skill set of individual students and universities 
last 3yr - forever , or school which teach manual jobs lasting 2-3yrs 
depending profession of your choice and after that you can study to be 
example engineer which lasting 3-6yrs again depending your individual 
choices and goals trying to achieve 
And every thing is free between 1st and last day in education including 
food and student loans and student welfare paying upkeep like rents, health 
care and some cash etc if don't study in home town or parents are less 
fortunate ones
comments.author: John Stoner For Life 77

comments.text:
+john stoner Yes the education system is messed up in the states. From 
kindergarden to the last year of high school (12th grade), nothing works 
for the benefit of a young student.
Then you get into secondary education. ANYTHING education related that is 
private in this country is absurdly expensive and only exist within a few 
reasons. 1) bragging rights. 2) religion. 3) resume. 
This country doesn't exist on "knowledge from experience" anymore. 
Employers want you to have a 2 or 4 year degree and a few years of 
experience on your resume for a entry level job in the field you are trying 
to enter.. sense it does not makes

comments.text:
Some students may think that, if it's only being used for web browsing & 
word processing, they could get away with using a tablet. However, in my 
opinion, tablets can be great for light computing tasks like emails & 
looking up info but I think that you should have a laptop because they can 
store large files like movies, has a real physical keyboard, USB ports, 
disc drive, & wired ethernet port. I will admit that tablets have an 
advantage in built-in 3/4G but 3/4G can easily be added to laptops
comments.author: TheWolfHowling

because you can also find out who will give you the most money for your 
used textbooks...that's a big deal for me.
